hexagrams.name: The Creative (乾 - Qián)
hexagrams.heart: Six unbroken lines, stacked like a ladder to the sky. Pure yang. The force that moves the stars without effort, that turns the seasons without hurry. Before any doing, there is this: the power simply to be, to generate, to begin. The Creative does not struggle—it creates by being itself, the way the sky does not try to be vast, it simply is.

ancient.rendering: THE CREATIVE works sublime success, Furthering through perseverance.

hexagrams.judgment: There is a power in you that precedes all action. It is not something you earn or achieve—it is your birthright, the original energy that brought you here. When you act from this place, success follows not because you forced it, but because you aligned with something larger. The four virtues are one: origin that unfolds, flow that encounters no obstacle, nature that finds its true expression, and the firmness that endures. Do not mistake this for ambition. The Creative does not grasp; it radiates.
hexagrams.image: The movement of heaven is full of power. Thus the superior person makes themselves strong and untiring. Heaven does not pause. It does not rush. It simply moves, endlessly, like breath, like a heartbeat. To be strong and untiring is not to push against the world, but to remain so deeply yourself that you never need to stop. Like the sky that holds the stars without effort, you hold your center through all seasons.
lines: Hidden dragon. Do not act. The power is there, coiled like a dragon beneath the earth, but the time is not yet ripe. To push now would be to break the sprout before it breaks the soil. Rest in the darkness. Let the roots grow. The world does not need to see you yet. It needs you to become real.

Dragon appearing in the field. It furthers one to see the great person. Now the first green shoot appears. Not yet a tree, but unmistakably alive. You emerge into the field of human affairs, and those with eyes to see recognize something genuine in you. Do not mistake this for fame or status. It is simply the natural result of being real—others feel it, the way they feel sunlight without being told.

All day long, the creative person is actively creating. At nightfall, their mind is still beset with cares. Danger. No blame. The work has begun, and it is good. But with doing comes the noise of doing—plans, worries, the endless chatter of 'what next.' This is the danger: that the activity consumes the stillness from which it came. The sage works all day, then returns to silence. Can you?

Wavering flight over the depths. No blame. Now you have climbed high enough to see the abyss. Below you, the vast unknown. Two paths open: to soar higher into the world's view, or to dive deep into solitude and self-discovery. Neither is wrong. The only mistake is to choose from fear. Ask the depths which way is yours.

Flying dragon in the heavens. It furthers one to see the great person. At last, full expression. The dragon that was hidden, then appearing, then active, then hovering, now flies free across the sky. This is not conquest—it is fulfillment. Like a tree that has reached its full height and now simply offers shade. Those who see you at this stage are blessed not by your power, but by your completion.

Arrogant dragon will have cause to repent. The sky has no top. To keep climbing beyond yourself is to leave the earth entirely, to become nothing. The dragon that forgets it once came from the depths loses its way. Pride is not the fall—it is the forgetting that you were ever small. Stay connected to the ground, even in flight.

lower.name: Qián (Heaven)
lower.nature: The creative, the originating, the power to begin

upper.name: Qián (Heaven)
upper.nature: The active, the moving, the power to continue

trigrams.description: Heaven above heaven. Movement generating more movement. This is not repetition, but the endless unfolding of what is genuine. Like one wave following another, each new, each the same ocean. The lower heaven is your inner source; the upper heaven is your outer expression. When they are the same, you live without division.

hexagrams.taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'The Tao never acts, yet nothing is left undone.' Hexagram 1 is the living proof. Pure yang, pure creative power—yet it does not grasp, demand, or strive. It simply is, and in its being, all things arise. The dragon does not try to be powerful; it is powerful, and so it flies. The sky does not try to be vast; it is vast, and so it holds the stars. The sage does not try to lead; they are real, and so others follow—not because they are pushed, but because they recognize something they already carry within themselves. This is the teaching of The Creative: before any doing, be. And from that being, let action flow like water from an endless spring.

hexagrams.name: The Receptive (坤 - Kūn)
hexagrams.heart: Six broken lines. Earth receiving heaven. The mare running across the endless plain, asking nothing, becoming everything. Where the Creative gives birth to ideas, the Receptive brings them into form. It does not initiate—it completes. It does not command—it supports. This is not weakness. The earth does not struggle to be fertile; it simply opens, and life springs forth.

ancient.chinese: 坤。元亨利牝馬之貞。君子有攸往，先迷後得主，利。西南得朋，東北喪朋。安貞吉。
ancient.rendering: THE RECEPTIVE brings about sublime success, Furthering through the perseverance of a mare. If the superior person undertakes something and tries to lead, they go astray; but if they follow, they find guidance. It is favorable to find friends in the west and south, to forego friends in the east and north. Quiet perseverance brings good fortune.

hexagrams.judgment: There is a power in you that does not push—it receives. Like soil receiving rain, like the valley receiving the stream, like the mare running not to conquer the plain but to become one with it. This is the perseverance of the mare: not stubbornness, but faithful, steady movement within the whole. To try to lead here is to lose the way. To follow—not weakly, but with full presence—is to find guidance. The Receptive teaches that some things come only when we stop reaching for them. They arrive in the space we have held open.
hexagrams.image: The earth's condition is receptive devotion. Thus the superior person carries the outer world with broad virtue. The earth does not select what it receives. It accepts rain and drought, seed and stone, the footstep and the resting body. Its virtue is its vast capacity to hold all things without judgment. In the same way, the wise one develops a heart wide enough to contain the world—not to control it, but to support it. This is true strength: to carry without complaint, to hold without possessing.
lines: Hoarfrost underfoot. Solid ice follows. The first sign—a chill in the air, frost on the grass. It seems small, insignificant. But frost is the beginning of ice. The Receptive teaches through accumulation. What you allow today, you invite tomorrow. Not as punishment, but as nature. Tend the small beginnings, for they become your ground.

Straight, square, great. No need for practice, nothing that does not further. The earth is straight—it follows its nature without deviation. It is square—it contains all things within its four directions. It is great—it holds everything without exception. When you are simply yourself, fully, without pretense, your actions become like the earth: direct, containing, vast. You need not practice being what you already are.

Hidden lines. One can remain persevering. If by chance you are in the service of a king, seek not works, but bring to completion. Sometimes the way is to be invisible. Not hidden because you are hiding, but hidden because the work does not need your name on it. Like the earth that supports the tree without needing to be seen in its branches, you complete things without claiming them. This is not self-effacement—it is the wisdom of knowing when your presence is the gift, not your label.

A tied-up sack. No blame, no praise. There are times when the wise one binds themselves like a sack—closed, contained, revealing nothing. This is not fear; it is appropriateness. When the world is not ready to receive, or when your inner work requires silence, you close. No blame follows, because you have harmed nothing. But also no praise, because praise comes from opening. Learn when to tie the sack, and when to loosen it.

A yellow lower garment. Supreme good fortune. Yellow is the color of earth, of the center, of balance. A lower garment is humble, close to the ground, yet essential. To wear yellow is to be rooted in the center. To wear the lower garment is to be content with what supports, not what shines. This is supreme good fortune: to be exactly where you belong, doing exactly what is yours to do, asking nothing more.

Dragons fight in the meadow. Their blood is black and yellow. When the receptive forgets its nature and tries to become creative, conflict follows. Dragons—creatures of heaven—descend to the meadow, the realm of earth. They fight. Their blood, the mingling of heaven (black) and earth (yellow), stains the grass. This is what happens when yielding becomes striving, when supporting becomes competing. The blood is not punishment—it is the natural consequence of being what you are not. Stay in your ground.

trigrams.description: Earth above earth. Devotion that deepens devotion. Not passivity, but active, faithful presence. The lower earth is your inner ground—your capacity to receive your own experience without judgment. The upper earth is your outer expression—your way of holding others with the same unconditional acceptance. When they are the same, you become ground for yourself and others.

hexagrams.taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'The supreme good is like water. It benefits all things without contention. It stays in lowly places that others despise. Thus it is near the Tao.' Hexagram 2 is water's elder sister—earth itself. Even lower than water, even more receptive. Earth asks nothing, claims nothing, yet all things return to it in the end. This is the power of true humility: not thinking less of yourself, but thinking of yourself less. The mare does not try to be fast like the dragon; she runs her own run, and in that running, she is complete. The Receptive teaches that to follow is not to be less—it is to find the one thing you were always meant to complete, and to complete it without needing to be seen doing so.

hexagrams.name: Difficulty at the Beginning (屯 - Zhūn)
hexagrams.heart: Thunder and rain. The storm that breaks the drought. Below, thunder stirs; above, rain falls. But between them, clouds still gather, confused, heavy. This is the moment after conception and before birth—the quickening, the first stirring, the struggle to emerge. Everything is here, potential fully present, but not yet delivered. Difficulty at the Beginning is not failure; it is the birth pangs of creation.

ancient.chinese: 屯。元亨利貞。勿用有攸往。利建侯。
ancient.rendering: Difficulty at the Beginning works supreme success, Furthering through perseverance. Do not use this for undertaking. It is favorable to appoint helpers.

hexagrams.judgment: The seed has sprouted, but the soil is hard. Do not mistake this struggle for a sign that you are on the wrong path. The beginning of anything real meets resistance—the world does not part easily to let the new in. Supreme success is promised, but not yet. First comes the work of rooting, of pushing against the dark earth. Do not undertake great journeys now. Instead, gather helpers, those who can steady you while you find your footing. The noble one does not go it alone at the beginning.
hexagrams.image: Clouds and thunder. Thus the noble one weaves the fabric of order. Thunder stirs below, clouds gather above, but the rain has not yet fallen. All the elements are present, but not yet resolved. In this tension, the wise one begins to weave—bringing together what is separate, ordering what is chaotic. Not by force, but by patient interconnection. Like a spider spinning its first thread across emptiness, you begin with what you have, trusting the web will hold.
lines: Hesitation and hindrance. It furthers one to remain persevering. It furthers one to appoint helpers. The first step is the hardest. The ground is uncertain, the way unclear. Do not charge forward blindly. Hesitation here is not weakness—it is the wise pause before commitment. Like testing the ice with one foot before trusting it with your whole weight, you wait, you feel, you gather those who can see what you cannot. The hesitation itself, when conscious, becomes part of the path.

Difficulties pile up. Horse and wagon part. Not a robber, but a suitor. The maiden is chaste, she does not pledge herself. Ten years, then she pledges. Things fall apart—the horse leaves the wagon, what was joined now separates. But this is not disaster; it is the natural sorting of what does not belong together. Wait, like the maiden who will not give herself to the wrong one. Even if it takes ten years, the right alignment will come. Do not force what is not ready to join.

Whoever hunts deer without the forester only enters the thicket. The noble one understands the signs of the times. It is better to give up than to continue. To pursue something without the proper guide, without understanding the territory, is to lose yourself in the thicket. The forester knows the land, knows the habits of the deer. If you hunt without them, you will stumble in blindness. There are times when giving up is not failure—it is the wisdom of recognizing you are not ready. The noble one reads the signs and knows when to wait.

Horse and wagon part. Seek union. To go brings good fortune. Everything acts favorably. After the separation, the seeking. The horse that left now returns, or a new horse appears. The scattering was not permanent—it was the clearing of space for a truer joining. Now you can seek, and the seeking itself is blessed. The movement that was forbidden in the first line is now possible, because the ground has been tested, the helpers gathered, the timing matured. Go now.

Difficulties in blessing. A little perseverance brings good fortune. Great perseverance brings misfortune. A small kindness offered at the right moment waters the struggling sprout. But to pour a flood on it, to try to force growth with great effort, drowns it. You are being blessed, but the blessing comes drop by drop. Accept the little that is given. Do not demand the full abundance before the plant can hold it. Patience in receiving is as important as patience in striving.

Horse and wagon part. Bloody tears flow. When the breaking is final, when separation is complete, there is grief. Bloody tears—the kind that come from the deepest place. This line does not console; it witnesses. Some difficulties end not in union but in loss. And yet, even this has its place in the great turning. The tears themselves water something new, somewhere, in another season. Let them flow.

lower.name: Zhèn (Thunder)
lower.nature: Arousing, stirring, the shock that initiates movement

upper.name: Kǎn (Water)
upper.nature: The abysmal, danger, the rain that has not yet fallen

trigrams.description: Thunder below, rain above. The stirring and the potential, but not yet the release. Thunder shakes the earth, rain gathers in clouds, but the downpour has not come. This is the moment of highest tension before creation breaks through. The thunder is your inner impulse to act; the water is the outer situation still forming. Both are real. Both are waiting.

hexagrams.taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'The Tao gives birth to one. One gives birth to two. Two gives birth to three. Three gives birth to ten thousand things.' Hexagram 3 is the three—the firstborn of Heaven and Earth, the beginning of the ten thousand things. And what is birth but difficulty? The Tao does not promise easy beginnings. It promises that beginnings are possible, that even the hardest soil will yield if the seed is true. The sprout does not fight the earth; it grows through it, using the pressure to strengthen itself. Your difficulties at the beginning are not obstacles to your path—they are the path. The rain will fall when the clouds are full enough. The thunder has already sounded.

hexagrams.name: Youthful Folly (蒙 - Méng)
hexagrams.heart: Every beginning is covered in mist. The mountain does not call the stream to itself—the stream finds its own way down, filling each hollow, learning the shape of the land as it flows. There is nothing wrong with not knowing. The trouble begins only when we pretend to know, or when we ask the same question again and again, hoping for a different answer.

ancient.chinese: 蒙。亨。匪我求童蒙。童蒙求我。初筮告。再三瀆。瀆則不告。利貞。
ancient.rendering: Youthful folly has success. I do not seek the young and inexperienced; they seek me. At the first casting, I instruct. If they ask two or three times, that is troublesome. To the troublesome, I give no instruction. Perseverance furthers.

hexagrams.judgment: The Sage does not chase after students. Wisdom cannot be forced on anyone. But when a true seeker arrives—humble, open, ready—the teaching appears naturally, like water finding its level.
hexagrams.image: A spring rises at the foot of the mountain. The noble one nurtures character by being thorough in all things. The spring does not leap to the valley in one bound. It fills each depression, seeps through each layer of stone, moves steadily and patiently. In the same way, we develop ourselves by attending to each small thing, skipping nothing. Character builds not in grand gestures but in the patient filling of every hollow place.
lines: Releasing ignorance. Using punishment to correct, removing the shackles. But persisting in punishment leads to regret. There is a time for discipline, for breaking the hard crust of old habits. But punishment alone cannot teach—it only restrains. The goal is to remove the shackles from the mind, not add more. If all you do is punish, you create a prisoner, not a student.

Embracing the ignorant with patience brings good fortune. Receiving even the simplest teachings. Like a son who can sustain his family. True strength is gentle. The one who teaches does not disdain the simplest question or the humblest student. Like a son who has matured enough to care for his parents, the wise one holds space for growth without judgment. This 包容 (bāoróng)—the capacity to contain and accept what is still forming.

Do not take this one as a companion. Seeing gold, they forget themselves. Nothing fruitful comes. This line warns against those who have no center. They chase after glitter, lose themselves in every new opportunity, and cannot be relied upon. But it also speaks to us: do not let your wanting exceed your integrity. When you forget yourself in pursuit of gain, you become someone no one should trust.

Bound in the chains of ignorance. Regret. This is the ignorance that comes from isolation. Cut off from those who are solid, stuck only with others who also don't know, the fool becomes entrenched. Regret follows—not as punishment, but as the natural consequence of refusing to grow.

Childlike ignorance. Good fortune. Here is the innocence we started with, but now it's chosen, not accidental. Complete openness. The mind that does not already know, so it can actually learn. This is the fertile emptiness the Tao Te Ching speaks of—the vessel that can be filled because it is not already full. Good fortune indeed.

Striking the ignorant. No advantage in injury. Advantage in warding off harm. When ignorance hardens into arrogance, there is a temptation to strike, to force understanding through violence. This never works—it only creates more resistance. Better to protect the fool from the consequences of their own folly where possible, while letting them learn at their own pace. You cannot beat wisdom into anyone.

trigrams.description: Water flows down the mountain, finding its way around rocks, filling crevices. The mountain simply is—still, present, allowing. The student flows; the teacher rests. Both are necessary.

hexagrams.taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'The wise are not learned; the learned are not wise.' Hexagram 4 honors a certain kind of not-knowing. Not the ignorance that refuses to learn, but the innocence that remains open. The spring does not know where it's going—it only knows how to flow, and the mountain teaches it the way by simply being there.

hexagrams.name: Waiting (需 - Xū)
hexagrams.heart: Clouds rising into heaven. Rain that has not yet fallen. Above, the vast openness of the sky; below, the gathering moisture. Nothing is wrong. Everything is exactly as it should be. But not yet complete. Waiting is not emptiness—it is fullness in suspension. The field does not curse the clouds for not releasing; it simply receives the shadow, the coolness, the promise. Waiting is the space between the promise and its fulfillment, and that space is sacred.

ancient.chinese: 需。有孚，光亨，貞吉。利涉大川。
ancient.rendering: Waiting. If you are sincere, you have light and success. Perseverance brings good fortune. It furthers one to cross the great water.

hexagrams.judgment: There is a time when the only right action is to wait. Not passive waiting, not anxious waiting—but sincere waiting, trust-filled waiting. You have done what needed doing; now the clouds must fill in their own time. This waiting has a quality of light. It is not dark, not desperate. It is the patient expectancy of a farmer after planting, of a lover before meeting, of a painter before the first brushstroke. To wait with sincerity is to remain present, open, unforced. When the time ripens, you will cross the great water—the great difficulty—as if it were nothing, because you did not exhaust yourself against it too soon.
hexagrams.image: Clouds rise up to heaven. The noble one eats and drinks, feasts with family and friends. The image is striking: clouds rise, but the rain does not fall. What does the wise one do? They do not stare anxiously at the sky. They do not pace and fret. They gather with those they love, share food, rest, nourish themselves. The waiting period is not empty time—it is time for replenishment. The fields cannot be forced to drink; the rain will come when the clouds are ready. Until then, tend to the human things. Eat. Drink. Be with your people. This waiting is itself a kind of harvest.
lines: Waiting in the meadow. It furthers one to abide in what endures. No blame. The meadow is open, grassy, peaceful—but exposed. You wait here, not yet in danger, but not yet sheltered. The key is to abide in what endures: your center, your practice, your connection to what is real beyond circumstance. Do not fill the waiting with distraction. Stay present in the open field, trusting that the enduring ground beneath you will hold.

Waiting on the sand. There is some gossip. The end brings good fortune. The sand shifts, washes away. It is less stable than the meadow. Words begin—gossip, criticism, the small irritations of those who do not understand your waiting. The sand does not hold footprints well, and neither do their words. Do not grasp at them. Let the gossip wash away like tide on sand. The end brings good fortune because you did not let the small disturbances move you from your center.

Waiting in the mud brings about the arrival of the enemy. Mud is not water and not land—it is the in-between that traps. If you wait here, in ambiguity, in half-measures, in the place where you are neither fully committed nor fully released, you attract what you do not want. The enemy arrives not because you are wrong, but because you are unclear. The mud itself calls them. If you find yourself here, recognize: the problem is not the enemy, but the muddy ground you chose.

Waiting in blood. Get out of the pit. Blood means wounding, the cost of waiting too long in the wrong place. Perhaps you waited in the mud, and the enemy came. Perhaps you waited in the sand, and the gossip cut deeper than you admitted. Now you are wounded, in the pit. The only instruction is: get out. Not by heroic effort, but by seeing clearly that you cannot stay. The pit does not release you—you release the pit. Climb. Any direction that is up.

Waiting at meat and drink. Perseverance brings good fortune. Here is the return to the image: clouds above, feast below. You have found your way back to nourishment. Not escape, not denial, but genuine replenishment. The waiting continues—the rain still has not fallen—but now you wait in the right way: surrounded by what sustains you, giving and receiving, resting in the presence of those who matter. This is not a retreat from the waiting; it is its deepest practice.

You fall into the pit. Three uninvited guests arrive. Honor them, and in the end there is good fortune. Even after waiting well, after feasting, after climbing out—you can fall again. The pit is always there, somewhere. But now, when you fall, guests come. Not enemies, not gossip, not mud—guests. They arrive uninvited, unexpected. And the instruction is: honor them. These are the helpers sent by the waiting itself, the ones who appear when you are least in control. Honor them, and the pit becomes a doorway.

lower.name: Qián (Heaven)
lower.nature: The creative, the strong, the power to act

trigrams.description: Heaven below, water above. Strength waiting under danger. The creative power is present, fully capable of action, but above it hangs the abyss, the rain not yet fallen. This is not weakness—it is appropriateness. The strong one knows when to let the clouds gather. The water above is not a threat to heaven; it is heaven's nourishment, coming in its own time. The strong wait because they are strong enough to wait.

hexagrams.taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'Do you have the patience to wait till your mud settles and the water is clear? Can you remain unmoving till the right action arises by itself?' Hexagram 5 is the answer: yes. Waiting is not the absence of action—it is the deepest form of trust. The clouds do not struggle to become rain; they simply gather, thicken, darken, until their weight becomes release. Your waiting is the same. You are not stuck; you are gathering. You are not passive; you are filling. When the clouds are ready, the rain falls without effort. When you are ready, the great water will be crossed as if it were always already crossed. Until then, eat. Drink. Be with your people. The rain knows its time.

hexagrams.name: Conflict (訟 - Sòng)
hexagrams.heart: Heaven above, water below. The upward drive of the creative, the downward pull of the abyss. They move against each other, not together. This is conflict—not necessarily war, but opposition, friction, the grating of two forces that cannot yet align. It arises when waiting fails, when patience is exhausted, when the clouds refuse to release and the earth grows dry. Conflict is not evil; it is the natural result of misalignment. But like fire, it can warm or it can burn.

ancient.chinese: 訟。有孚窒惕，中吉，終凶。利見大人。不利涉大川。
ancient.rendering: Conflict. You are sincere but blocked. Be cautious in the middle, good fortune; to the end, misfortune. It furthers one to see the great person. It does not further one to cross the great water.

hexagrams.judgment: You feel the blockage. Your sincerity, your genuine intention, meets resistance. The other does not hear, does not yield. In the middle of conflict, if you remain conscious, there can be good fortune—not because you win, but because you learn. But if you pursue conflict to the end, seeking victory, seeking to be right, misfortune follows. The wise one, when conflict arises, seeks out the great person—the one who sees clearly, who holds the center. Do not try to cross the great water now. The crossing requires trust, and trust is what conflict has eroded. Wait. See the great person. Let their clarity become yours.
hexagrams.image: Heaven and water go their opposite ways. The noble one begins every undertaking with careful consideration. Heaven rises, water descends. Their paths diverge. This is the image of conflict: two forces moving in opposite directions. What can the noble one learn from this? To begin every undertaking with careful consideration. Before action, before commitment, weigh the direction. If two are to go together, they must first align. If alignment is not possible, better to know before the journey begins than to fight over which way to turn halfway through.
lines: Do not perpetuate the conflict. There is some gossip, but in the end it is good fortune. The conflict is small, a whisper, a misunderstanding. Do not feed it. If you let it drop, it will dissolve. The gossip is like a spark—if you do not add fuel, it dies. To perpetuate it would be to make it real. Let it go, and good fortune follows.

Unable to contend, return and flee. The people of his town, three hundred households, are without blame. There are battles you cannot win, conflicts you cannot resolve. To recognize this is not cowardice; it is wisdom. Return, flee, not in shame but in clarity. The people of your place—your community, your true companions—will understand. They do not blame you for refusing a fight that could only destroy. Survival is sometimes the highest virtue.

Feed on old virtue. Perseverance brings danger. In the end, good fortune comes. If you follow the king's business, do not seek glory. Old virtue—what you have built before, the integrity you have already cultivated—can sustain you for a time. But if you rely on it alone, and persevere in conflict, danger comes. The line advises: in the midst of conflict, do not seek to be seen, to be honored. Do your work quietly. Let the old virtue be your ground, not your banner. In the end, good fortune comes because you did not make yourself a target.

Unable to contend, you return and change your purpose. You find peace in perseverance. Good fortune. The conflict has shown you that your original aim was not possible, not right, not yours. So you return, not defeated but redirected. You change your purpose. This is not surrender; it is adaptation. Water does not fight the rock; it flows around it, and in flowing, finds its way to the sea. To find peace in perseverance—the perseverance of the changed course—is good fortune indeed.

Contending before him. Supreme good fortune. Here, the great person appears. You bring your conflict before one who sees clearly, who holds no personal stake. In their presence, the truth emerges, and the conflict resolves not by victory but by clarity. This is supreme good fortune: to be seen truly, to have the knot untied by a steady hand. The great person does not take sides; they reveal the center.

Even if by chance you receive the leather belt, by the end of the morning it will have been snatched from you three times. The leather belt is a symbol of rank, of victory, of having won. But in conflict, winning is not possessing. What you gain through contention you cannot hold. By the end of the morning—quickly, inevitably—it is taken. Three times, meaning completely. This is the ultimate teaching of Conflict: there is no victory in it that lasts. The only true resolution is the one that restores alignment, not the one that proves you right.

trigrams.description: Water below, heaven above. Water wants to descend, heaven wants to rise. They move in opposite directions. This is the geometry of conflict—not evil, but misalignment. The danger of water meets the strength of heaven. When forces pull apart, friction arises. The wise one reads this image and knows: before acting, consider direction. If two are to go together, they must first align.

hexagrams.taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'The best warriors are not violent. The best fighters do not lose their temper. The greatest conquerors do not engage.' Hexagram 6 is the teaching of non-engagement. Not because you are weak, but because you understand that conflict, once entered, has its own momentum. It carries you toward the leather belt that will be snatched away by morning. The wise one does not win—they align. If alignment is not possible, they wait. If waiting is not possible, they seek the great person. Only when clarity replaces contention does the great water become crossable. The Tao does not fight; it flows around obstacles. In the end, the rock is still there, but the water has reached the sea.

hexagrams.name: The Army (師 - Shī)
hexagrams.heart: Water flowing underground. Hidden, unseen, but moving with purpose. Above, the earth; below, the stream that nourishes it. This is the army—not the visible force, but the disciplined structure that supports from beneath. The army is not war; it is organization. It is the capacity to act together, to move as one, to bring order out of chaos. The true leader does not stand above, waving banners. They flow underground, unseen, making the earth fertile.

ancient.rendering: The Army. Perseverance. The old man brings good fortune. No blame.

hexagrams.judgment: There are times when collective action is necessary. Not for conquest, not for glory—but for protection, for order, for the survival of what matters. In such times, the leader must be like the old man: experienced, calm, without personal ambition. They do not seek the army; the army seeks them. They lead not because they want power, but because they know how to serve. Perseverance here means staying true to the purpose, not getting drunk on the power. If the leader remains a channel, not a source, there is good fortune and no blame.
hexagrams.image: Water flows underground. The noble one nurtures the people with generosity and protects them from harm. Water underground is invisible, but without it, the earth would be barren. The noble one, like this hidden water, nurtures without showing. They are generous—not with display, but with steady, reliable support. They protect—not with force visible, but with structure that holds. The army at its best is not seen; it is felt in the order it maintains, the safety it provides, the fields it allows to be planted in peace.
lines: The army goes forth in proper order. If not, misfortune threatens. The first movement must be correct. Every step, every command, every soldier must know their place. Discipline is not punishment—it is the shared understanding that allows many to act as one. If the order is not proper, if there is confusion or favoritism, misfortune follows not as judgment but as consequence. The army that marches in chaos defeats itself before it meets any enemy.

In the midst of the army, good fortune. No blame. The king bestows a triple commendation. The leader is not above the army; they are in its midst. They do not command from a distance, safe and separate. They are present, sharing the conditions, bearing the same risks. This presence is itself good fortune—the army feels it, trusts it. The king bestows triple commendation not because the leader sought it, but because true leadership, when witnessed, naturally calls forth honor. The leader accepts it without grasping.

The army may carry corpses in the wagon. Misfortune. When the leader is weak, when they try to command without capacity, the army carries corpses—dead weight, useless orders, hollow authority. The wagon, meant for supplies, becomes a hearse. This is misfortune not because the enemy is strong, but because the leader is not. Better to have no army than an army led by one who cannot lead.

The army retreats. No blame. There is no shame in knowing when advance is not possible. The army that retreats in good order, preserving its strength, its cohesion, its purpose, commits no fault. The blame is not in the movement but in the motivation. If retreat is strategy, it is wisdom. If retreat is fear disguised, it will show. The line does not judge; it observes. The wise commander knows the difference.

There is game in the fields. It furthers one to capture them. No blame. The eldest son leads the army. The younger piles up corpses. Perseverance brings misfortune. When the purpose is clear—game in the fields, sustenance for the people—it is right to act. The eldest son, the capable one, leads. But if the younger, the unprepared, tries to take charge, they pile up corpses—waste, failure, unnecessary death. To persevere in this error brings misfortune. Know who should lead. Let them lead.

The great ruler issues commands, founds states, invests families. Inferior people should not be employed. After the work is done, after the army has served its purpose, the great ruler returns to the ways of peace. They found states, not garrisons. They invest families, not soldiers. They issue commands for life, not death. And in all this, they remember: inferior people—those who love war, who seek power, who would make the army their career—should not be employed. The army exists to make itself unnecessary. The leader who forgets this becomes the very thing they were meant to oppose.

trigrams.description: Water underground. The hidden stream that nourishes the earth without showing itself. This is the true nature of organized force: not the visible army, but the discipline that flows beneath, making collective action possible. The water is dangerous—it can flood, it can drown—but underground, it is life. The army, when rightly led, is the same: hidden, disciplined, life-giving.

hexagrams.taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'A good leader is one who, when the work is done, the people say, "We did this ourselves."' Hexagram 7 is the manual for that kind of leadership. The army that flows underground, unseen, does not need to be seen to be effective. The leader who is in the midst, not above, does not need to be praised to be followed. When the battle is over, when the state is founded, when the families are invested, the people do not say, 'What a great general.' They say, 'We did this. We were safe. We were fed. We lived.' And the leader, like water underground, has already moved on to the next place that needs nourishing. This is the highest art of the army: to make itself unnecessary, to return to the earth, to let the fields speak for themselves.

hexagrams.name: Holding Together (比 - Bǐ)
hexagrams.heart: Water flowing to the earth. Not forced, not pushed—simply seeking its own level, finding the low places, joining with what is already there. This is holding together: the natural affinity that draws like to like, that creates community not by decree but by mutual recognition. The army organized; now it must unite. Not through command, but through the quiet gravity of shared purpose.

ancient.chinese: 比。吉。原筮元永貞，无咎。不寧方來，後夫凶。
ancient.rendering: Holding Together brings good fortune. Consult the oracle further for the sublime, enduring perseverance, and no blame. Those who are uncertain gradually join. Those who come too late meet misfortune.

hexagrams.judgment: Good fortune. Not because holding together is easy, but because it is natural. Water seeks earth; earth receives water. This is the way of things. To hold together with others who share your center is not a compromise—it is a completion. Consult deeply before committing. Do not rush into alliance. Let the sublime, enduring perseverance guide you: is this true? Will it last? Can you give yourself to it without losing yourself? Those who are uncertain will come in their own time, drawn by the same gravity that brought you. But those who come too late, who wait until the bond is already formed and try to force their way in, meet misfortune. The circle closes. Timing is part of truth.
hexagrams.image: On the earth, water. The noble ones of old gave to the various kingdoms, befriended the feudal lords. Water on earth: it seeks the low places, fills the hollows, connects what is separate. The ancient rulers understood this image. They did not conquer; they gave. They did not control; they befriended. They honored the existing bonds of the kingdoms, the natural alliances of the lords. Holding together is not about creating bonds where none exist—it is about recognizing and honoring the bonds that are already there, and adding to them generously.
lines: Hold to him in truth and loyalty. No blame. This truth is like the heart of the earth—steady, unmoving, reliable. In the beginning of any alliance, there is only this: truth and loyalty. Not grand promises, not elaborate contracts. Just the simple, unwavering commitment to be real with each other. From this, all else grows. No blame follows such a beginning.

Hold to him inwardly. Perseverance brings good fortune. The bond is not for display. It does not need witnesses or ceremonies. It is inward, felt in the depths, known without being spoken. To hold inwardly is to carry the other in your heart, to be connected even when apart, to act in the world with their presence as a silent companion. This inward holding, if persevered in, brings good fortune—not as reward, but as the natural flowering of deep connection.

You hold to such as are not your own kind. The bond you seek is with those who do not share your center, your values, your way. This is not necessarily wrong—sometimes we are called to bridge differences. But it is difficult, and the line offers no judgment, only observation. If you hold to those not your own kind, you must be prepared for the friction, the misunderstanding, the constant translation between worlds. It can be done, but it is not the same as the water-seeking-earth of true affinity.

Outwardly holding to him. Perseverance brings good fortune. Sometimes the bond begins on the outside—through shared work, shared circumstance, shared necessity. This is not shallow; it is the path by which many deep alliances form. The farmer who helps the neighbor build a barn, the soldier who fights beside a stranger, the parent who meets another at the school gate—outward holding can become inward, over time, through perseverance. Good fortune follows not because the bond was deep from the start, but because it was given the chance to deepen.

Manifestation of holding. The king takes the hunt in the encircling park. Those who come from within are not caught. Those who come from without are caught. The hunt: the king circles the game, driving it toward the center. But those who are already within the circle, who belong there by nature, are not caught—they are recognized. Those who come from without, who do not belong, are caught. This is the discernment of true holding. Not exclusion, but clarity. The circle knows who is inside and who is not. The king does not decide; the circle reveals.

He finds no head for holding. Misfortune. To hold together without a head—without a center, without a leader, without a shared focal point—is to be a body without a spine. The bond dissolves into confusion. Each pulls in their own direction. What was meant to unite becomes a source of fragmentation. This is misfortune not because heads are necessary for their own sake, but because without one, the holding has nothing to hold to.

lower.name: Kūn (Earth)
lower.nature: The receptive, yielding, the ground that receives

trigrams.description: Water on earth. The water flows to the earth, finding the low places, filling the hollows, creating lakes and rivers and wetlands. This is not conquest—it is affinity. The earth does not resist the water; it receives it. The water does not force the earth; it seeks it. Their holding together is the most natural thing in the world. And from their union, life springs forth in abundance.

hexagrams.taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'The highest goodness is like water. Water benefits all things and does not contend. It stays in lowly places that others despise. Thus it is near the Tao.' Hexagram 8 is water finding its level—not by contending, but by flowing. The bonds that hold are not forced; they are discovered. You do not create community; you recognize it. You do not manufacture loyalty; you embody it. Like water finding earth, you simply go where your nature leads, and there you find your people. Those who come late, who try to join after the bond is formed, meet misfortune—not because they are excluded, but because they mistook timing. The water was already there, already flowing. The wise one arrives when the water is still gathering, not after it has found the sea.

hexagrams.name: The Taming Power of the Small (小畜 - Xiǎo Xù)
hexagrams.heart: Wind above, heaven below. The gentle persistently softens the strong. Clouds gather but rain does not fall—yet. This is not failure but preparation. The small accumulates power not through force but through patience, like wind shaping stone over centuries. What cannot be stopped directly is gently redirected.

ancient.chinese: 小畜。亨。密雲不雨，自我西郊。
ancient.rendering: The Taming Power of the Small has success. Dense clouds, no rain from our western region.

hexagrams.judgment: There are times when the small must tame the large, when gentleness must guide strength. This is not accomplished through confrontation but through subtle, persistent influence. The clouds gather—power accumulates—but the rain does not fall because the time is not yet ripe. Success comes not from forcing the issue but from trusting the process. Like wind over heaven, you cannot see the change happening, but it is. The western region speaks of the place where the sun sets—completion is near, but not yet here.
hexagrams.image: The wind drives across heaven. The noble one refines the outward aspect of their nature. Wind moves invisibly but shapes everything it touches. The wise one, like the wind, works on themselves—not through dramatic transformation but through daily refinement. Each small adjustment, each gentle correction, accumulates into character. You cannot force growth; you can only create the conditions for it.
lines: Return to the way. How could there be blame in this? Good fortune. When you find yourself straying, returning is not failure—it is wisdom. The way is not a straight line but a spiral. You leave it to learn, then return having learned. There is no shame in this. Good fortune follows because you have not lost yourself; you have found yourself again.

He allows himself to be drawn into returning. Good fortune. Sometimes you do not find your way back alone. Someone, something, draws you gently toward home. Accept this help. To be drawn back is not weakness—it is the recognition that you are part of a larger whole. The one who draws you is not your master but your mirror, showing you what you already know.

The spokes burst out of the wagon wheels. Man and wife roll their eyes. The small taming has gone too far. Restraint becomes imprisonment. When the wagon's spokes burst, the vehicle cannot move. When partners roll their eyes at each other, connection breaks. This is what happens when gentle guidance becomes control. The small must tame through trust, not force. Otherwise, everything falls apart.

If you are sincere, blood vanishes and fear gives way. No blame. Sincerity dissolves what force cannot touch. Blood—symbol of injury, of conflict—vanishes when you approach with genuine heart. Fear gives way not because the danger is gone but because you are no longer feeding it. When you are sincere, there is nothing to defend, nothing to prove. No blame follows because you have not fought; you have simply been real.

If you are sincere and loyally attached, you are rich in your neighbor. True wealth is not what you accumulate but what you share. When you are sincere and loyal, your neighbor becomes your treasure. You are rich not because you have much but because you have each other. The small taming succeeds through connection, not isolation. Your neighbor's success is your success; their safety is your safety.

The rain comes, there is rest. This is due to the lasting effect of character. Perseverance brings the woman into danger. The moon is nearly full. If the superior person persists, misfortune comes. At last, the rain falls. The tension releases. But this is not the time to push further. The moon is nearly full—it cannot become more without waning. If you persist now, if you try to hold onto the moment, you turn blessing into burden. Rest in what has been achieved. Let the rain be enough.

lower.name: Qián (Heaven)
lower.nature: The creative, the strong, the power to act

upper.name: Xùn (Wind)
upper.nature: The gentle, the penetrating, the persistent influence

trigrams.description: Wind above heaven. The invisible shapes the visible. The gentle persistently influences the strong. This is not conquest but cultivation. The wind does not stop heaven; it guides it, shapes it, refines it. The small tames the large not by opposing it but by being consistently, gently present.

hexagrams.taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'The soft overcomes the hard. The gentle overcomes the rigid.' Hexagram 9 is the proof. Wind—soft, invisible, seemingly powerless—shapes the clouds, directs the rain, erodes the mountains. It does not fight; it flows. It does not demand; it persists. The small taming power is the power of the Tao itself: not the force that breaks but the presence that transforms. Clouds gather. Rain will come. But not because you forced it. Because you waited, refined, trusted. The wind knows: what is shaped gently lasts. What is forced breaks.

hexagrams.name: Treading (履 - Lǚ)
hexagrams.heart: Heaven above, the lake below. The highest and the lowest, connected by careful steps. To tread is to move through the world with awareness, knowing that some ground is sacred, some paths are dangerous. The tiger's tail is stepped on—yet there is no bite. This is not luck but the result of moving with respect, with attention, with the humility of one who knows they are walking through something larger than themselves.

ancient.rendering: Treading. Treading on the tail of the tiger. It does not bite. Success.

hexagrams.judgment: There is a way to move through dangerous situations without being harmed. It is not through boldness or avoidance but through treading carefully, respectfully, aware of the power around you. The tiger represents the forces that could destroy you—authority, nature, the unconscious, the divine. To tread on its tail is to risk everything. But if you move with the right quality of attention, if you honor what you walk upon, the tiger does not bite. Success comes not from conquering the tiger but from walking so lightly that it barely notices you.
hexagrams.image: Heaven above, the lake below. The noble one discriminates between high and low, and thereby brings order to the thoughts of the people. Heaven is high, the lake is low. This is not inequality but natural order. The wise one sees this and does not try to flatten the difference but to honor it. By discriminating between what is high and what is low, between what is appropriate and what is not, they bring clarity to the world. Order comes not from making everything the same but from recognizing the proper place of each thing.
lines: Simple conduct. To go forward is without blame. When your conduct is simple, unadorned, without pretense, you can move forward without fear. Complexity brings confusion; simplicity brings clarity. Do not try to be more than you are. Do not dress your intentions in fine clothes. Walk as you are, and the path will open.

Treading a smooth, level course. The perseverance of a dark person brings good fortune. The path is smooth, but this does not mean you can be careless. The dark person—one who is humble, who does not seek the spotlight—perseveres and finds good fortune. When the way is easy, the temptation is to become careless. Stay humble. Stay attentive. The smooth path is a gift, not a right.

A one-eyed person is able to see. A lame person is able to walk. They tread on the tail of the tiger. The tiger bites. Misfortune. A soldier acts on behalf of the great ruler. When you are not fully prepared—when you see with one eye, walk with one leg—and yet you take the risk, disaster follows. The tiger bites. This is not punishment; it is consequence. But there is another way: the soldier who acts not for themselves but for the great ruler. When you serve something larger, when your action is not about you, even danger can be transformed.

They tread on the tail of the tiger. Caution and circumspection lead ultimately to good fortune. The tiger's tail is stepped on again. But this time, the outcome is different. Why? Because of caution and circumspection. Because of the quality of attention. You cannot control the tiger, but you can control how you approach it. Move carefully. Be aware. Good fortune follows not because the danger is gone but because you have met it with the right spirit.

Resolute conduct. Perseverance with awareness of danger. There are times when you must be resolute, when hesitation is more dangerous than action. But this resoluteness must be tempered with awareness of danger. Do not confuse boldness with wisdom. Move forward, yes, but with your eyes open. Perseverance without awareness is recklessness. Perseverance with awareness is courage.

Look to your conduct and weigh the favorable signs. When everything is fulfilled, turn around. When you have reached the top, when everything is complete, there is one more step: turn around. Look back at the path you have walked. Weigh the favorable signs, the unfavorable ones, all of it. This is not nostalgia; it is integration. The journey is not complete until you have understood it. Then, and only then, can you begin again.

lower.name: Duì (Lake)
lower.nature: The joyful, the open, the receptive surface

upper.name: Qián (Heaven)
upper.nature: The creative, the strong, the power above

trigrams.description: Heaven above, lake below. The highest and the lowest in their proper relationship. The lake reflects heaven, receives it, holds it in its surface. This is treading: moving between the heights and depths with awareness, with respect. The lake does not try to become heaven; heaven does not try to fill the lake. Each is in its place, and in that placement, there is harmony.

hexagrams.taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'The sage walks without leaving tracks.' Hexagram 10 is the art of treading so lightly that the tiger does not notice. Not because you are hiding, but because you are not imposing. The sage moves through the world without forcing, without demanding, without leaving the scars of their passage. The lake reflects heaven without trying to capture it. The tiger allows the tail to be stepped on because the foot that steps is not heavy with ego. To tread well is to be present without being present. To walk through danger without creating more danger. This is the way: light, aware, respectful. The tiger knows. The tiger allows. Success.

hexagrams.name: Peace (泰 - Tài)
hexagrams.heart: Earth above, heaven below. The impossible made real. Heaven's light rises; earth's weight descends. They meet in the middle, and in that meeting, everything flourishes. This is peace—not the absence of conflict but the presence of harmony. The small departs; the great arrives. Not through struggle but through the natural order finally aligning.

ancient.rendering: Peace. The small departs, the great arrives. Good fortune. Success.

hexagrams.judgment: There are times when everything aligns, when the light rises and the heavy descends, when what should be above is above and what should be below is below. This is peace. It does not come from forcing things into place but from allowing them to find their natural position. The small—the petty, the superficial, the temporary—departs on its own. The great—the enduring, the meaningful, the true—arrives without being summoned. Good fortune and success are not rewards here; they are the natural state when things are as they should be.
hexagrams.image: Heaven and earth unite. The image of Peace. Thus the ruler divides and completes the course of heaven and earth, and so aids the people. Heaven and earth are separate, yet in this hexagram, they unite. Their union is peace. The ruler, seeing this, does not try to control but to facilitate—dividing what needs dividing, completing what needs completing, always in service of the natural order. The people are aided not by grand gestures but by the ruler's alignment with heaven and earth. When the top is in harmony with the bottom, everyone flourishes.
lines: When ribbon grass is pulled up, the sod comes with it. Each according to their kind. To go forward brings good fortune. One thing leads to another. When you pull ribbon grass, the whole sod comes up—roots intertwined, each blade connected to the whole. So it is with action. One right movement pulls up a whole network of right movements. Each according to their kind: the good draws the good, the true draws the true. To go forward now is to move with this current. Good fortune is not something you chase; it is something you join.

Bearing with the uncultured in gentleness, fording the river with resolution, not neglecting what is distant, not worrying about what is near. The superior person knows how to hold both gentleness and resolution. The uncultured are not rejected; they are borne with, given time. The river is not avoided; it is forded with determination. What is distant is not forgotten; what is near is not obsessively managed. This is balance. This is peace—not the absence of difficulty but the presence of wisdom in meeting it.

No plain not followed by a slope. No going not followed by a return. He who remains persevering in danger is without blame. Do not worry about this truth; enjoy the good fortune that is still yours. Every plain has its slope. Every going has its return. This is not pessimism; it is reality. Peace does not last forever—not because it is fragile but because nothing lasts forever. The one who remains persevering in danger, who does not panic when the slope appears, is without blame. Do not worry about the inevitable change. Enjoy the peace while it is here. It is enough.

They flutter, not rich in their neighbor. They do not warn one another. The approach is not from outside but from within. When things begin to shift, when peace starts to tilt toward its opposite, it happens from the inside. They flutter—nervous, uncertain, not rich in their neighbor, meaning disconnected from each other. They do not warn one another because they are too focused on their own uncertainty. This is how peace ends: not with a crash but with a slow disconnection. Notice the fluttering. Reconnect before it is too late.

The sovereign I gives his daughter in marriage. This brings blessing and supreme good fortune. When the highest gives to the lower, when there is genuine exchange between the top and the bottom, blessing follows. The sovereign's daughter—what is most precious—is given in marriage, not as conquest but as union. This is how peace is maintained: through genuine giving, through the willingness of the high to connect with the low. Supreme good fortune comes not from holding onto power but from sharing it.

The wall falls back into the moat. Use no army now. Make your commands known within your own town. Perseverance brings humiliation. The wall that protected you falls. Do not try to rebuild it with force. Do not summon the army. Instead, make your commands known within your own town—attend to what is yours to attend to, let go of what is not. If you try to hold on through force, through perseverance in the old way, humiliation follows. Peace has ended. Do not fight its ending. Attend to your own house. Let the wall fall.

lower.name: Qián (Heaven)
lower.nature: The creative, the light, the rising force

upper.name: Kūn (Earth)
upper.nature: The receptive, the heavy, the descending force

trigrams.description: Heaven below, earth above. The natural order inverted and yet harmonious. Heaven's light rises naturally; earth's weight descends naturally. They meet, they mingle, they create the conditions for life. This is peace: not stagnation but dynamic balance. The light does not stay below; the heavy does not stay above. They move toward each other, and in that movement, everything flourishes.

hexagrams.taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'When the Tao is present in the world, swift horses are used to carry manure. When the Tao is absent from the world, warhorses are bred on the commons.' Hexagram 11 is the Tao present. In peace, the strong horses carry manure—useful, humble work. There is no need for warhorses because there is no conflict to fight. Heaven and earth unite not through effort but through allowing. The light rises; the heavy falls. This is not something you create; it is something you allow. Peace is not achieved; it is recognized. It was always here, beneath the noise. When the small departs and the great arrives, you do not celebrate. You simply notice that things are as they should be. This is enough.

hexagrams.name: Standstill (否 - Pǐ)
hexagrams.heart: Heaven above, earth below. Each in their proper place, yet separated. Heaven rises; earth sinks. They do not meet. This is standstill—not chaos but stagnation. The great departs; the small arrives. Not as punishment but as the natural consequence of disconnection. When the high will not descend and the low will not rise, nothing flows. Nothing grows. Nothing changes.

ancient.chinese: 否。否之匪人。不利君子貞。大往小來。
ancient.rendering: Standstill. It does not further the perseverance of the superior person. The great departs, the small arrives.

hexagrams.judgment: There are times when heaven and earth do not meet, when the light rises away from the dark and the dark sinks away from the light. This is standstill. It is not that things are wrong; things are simply not connecting. The superior person cannot persevere here—not because they are weak but because perseverance requires movement, and there is none. The great departs—not forever, but for now. The small arrives—the petty, the superficial, the temporary. This is not the time to fight it. This is the time to wait, to conserve, to remember that standstill, like peace, is a season. It will pass.
hexagrams.image: Heaven and earth do not unite. The image of Standstill. Thus the superior person falls back upon their inner worth in order to escape the difficulties. They do not permit themselves to be honored with revenue. When heaven and earth do not unite, the wise one does not try to force them. Instead, they fall back upon their inner worth. They cultivate what cannot be taken away. They do not seek honor, do not accept revenue, do not try to profit from a time that offers nothing. This is not withdrawal from the world; it is withdrawal into the self, where the real work can continue even when the outer world is frozen.
lines: When ribbon grass is pulled up, the sod comes with it. Each according to their kind. Perseverance brings good fortune and success. The same image as Peace, but here it means something different. In standstill, when one thing is pulled, everything connected to it comes too—but what comes is more standstill. The small attracts the small. The stagnant attracts the stagnant. Perseverance here means staying true to yourself even when everything around you is pulling toward stagnation. Good fortune and success come not from changing the situation but from not letting the situation change you.

They bear with the uncultured in gentleness. The furor of the crowd. Good fortune for the stagnant. Success for the great person. In standstill, the uncultured are not just present; they are furiously present. The crowd has its way. For the stagnant, this is good fortune—they thrive in chaos. But for the great person, there is a different success: the success of bearing with it in gentleness, of not becoming what they behold. You cannot stop the furor, but you do not have to join it. This is your success: to remain yourself when everything encourages you to become less.

They bear with shame. The superior person finds good fortune in standstill. There is shame in standstill—not because you caused it but because you are living through it. The superior person bears this shame without denying it, without pretending it is not there. And in this bearing, in this honest acknowledgment, good fortune is found. Not the good fortune of success but the good fortune of integrity. You have not lied to yourself. You have not pretended the standstill is peace. This honesty is your anchor.

They who act at the command of the highest remain without blame. Those who are like-minded partake of the blessing. In standstill, action is only possible when it comes from the highest command—not from ego, not from ambition, but from the deepest knowing. If you act from this place, you remain without blame. And those who are like-minded, who also act from the highest, partake of the blessing. You are not alone. Even in standstill, there are others. Find them. Act together. The blessing is small but real.

Standstill is giving way. Good fortune for the great person. But what if they say, 'What if it does not give way?' The standstill is beginning to shift. It is giving way. Good fortune comes to the great person who recognizes this and does not try to force it. But there is doubt: 'What if it does not give way?' This doubt is natural. Do not suppress it. Hold it alongside the knowing that all things change. The standstill will end. The question is not if but when. And when it does, will you be ready?

The standstill comes to an end. First standstill, then good fortune. It does not last. It cannot last. Nothing lasts. The standstill comes to an end not because you forced it but because its time is complete. First standstill, then good fortune—not as reward but as sequence. Winter gives way to spring not because winter was bad but because that is the way of things. Remember this when you are in the thick of it. It does not last. You will not always feel this way. The standstill will end. And when it does, you will be here, having borne it, having remained yourself. This is enough.

lower.name: Kūn (Earth)
lower.nature: The receptive, the heavy, the sinking force

upper.name: Qián (Heaven)
upper.nature: The creative, the light, the rising force

trigrams.description: Heaven above, earth below. Each in their proper place, yet separated. Heaven rises naturally; earth sinks naturally. They move away from each other. This is standstill: not conflict but disconnection. The light goes up; the dark goes down. No meeting. No mingling. No life. This is the opposite of Peace, and yet it is equally natural. Standstill is not a mistake; it is a season. It will pass.

hexagrams.taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'The Tao that can be told is not the eternal Tao.' Hexagram 12 is the untellable time. Standstill cannot be explained away, cannot be fixed, cannot be optimized. It simply is. Heaven and earth do not unite, and no amount of wishing will make them. The sage does not fight this. They fall back on their inner worth. They cultivate the invisible. They wait. Not anxiously, not desperately, but with the patience of one who knows that winter is not the end of the story. The standstill will end. The great will return. But not because you demanded it. Because the Tao moves in cycles, and you are part of that movement. Rest now. Conserve. The standstill is not your enemy. It is your teacher.

hexagrams.name: Fellowship with People (同人 - Tóng Rén)
hexagrams.heart: Heaven above, fire below. The light rises to meet the light. Fire climbs toward heaven; heaven opens to receive it. This is fellowship—not the shallow connection of shared interests but the deep bond of shared purpose. People gathered not around a person but around a principle. The open field, the clear sky, the fire that burns without consuming. This is how humans are meant to be together.

ancient.chinese: 同人。同人于野。亨。利涉大川。利君子貞。
ancient.rendering: Fellowship with People. Fellowship in the open field. Success. It furthers one to cross the great water. It furthers the perseverance of the superior person.

hexagrams.judgment: There is a way to be with others that does not diminish you or them. It is fellowship in the open field—no walls, no gates, no exclusions. Anyone can enter. Anyone can leave. This is not weakness; it is strength. Only what is genuine can survive such openness. Success comes not from controlling who is in and who is out but from being so clear in your purpose that the right people find you. The great water can be crossed because you are not alone. The superior person perseveres not despite the fellowship but because of it. Together, what is impossible alone becomes possible.
hexagrams.image: Heaven together with fire. The image of Fellowship with People. Thus the superior person organizes the clans and distinguishes things. Heaven and fire are both light, both rising, both clear. Their fellowship is natural. The wise one, seeing this, organizes the clans—not by force but by clarity. They distinguish things—not to divide but to clarify. When people know what they stand for, when things are clear, fellowship happens on its own. You do not create it; you create the conditions for it.
lines: Fellowship at the gate. No blame. Fellowship at the gate means it has just begun. You are at the threshold, not yet fully inside, not yet fully committed. This is not a problem. It is the beginning. No blame follows because you have not pretended to be further along than you are. Stand at the gate. See who comes. Let the fellowship reveal itself.

Fellowship in the clan. Humiliation. When fellowship is limited to the clan—to those who look like you, think like you, come from where you come from—it becomes small. It becomes exclusion disguised as connection. This brings humiliation not because the clan is bad but because fellowship is meant to be larger. Do not mistake comfort for connection. Do not mistake familiarity for fellowship. Open the gates. Let others in.

He hides weapons in the thicket; he climbs the high hill in front of it. For three years he does not rise up. Sometimes fellowship requires preparation. Weapons are hidden—not for attack but for protection. The high hill is climbed—not for dominance but for perspective. Three years pass without rising up because the time is not right. Fellowship cannot be rushed. Wait. Prepare. Watch. When the time comes, you will know. Until then, do not force it.

He climbs up on his wall; he cannot attack. Good fortune. The wall is there, but you cannot—or will not—attack from it. This is restraint. This is wisdom. Good fortune follows because you have recognized that some battles do not need to be fought. The wall protects you; you do not need to use it as a platform for aggression. Fellowship grows not from conquest but from the willingness to lay down arms. Climb the wall if you must. But do not attack. Good fortune waits on the other side of restraint.

Fellowship with people. First they weep and wail, but afterward they laugh. After great struggles they succeed. True fellowship is not easy. First there is weeping and wailing—the pain of breaking old patterns, of letting go of exclusions, of opening the gates. But afterward, laughter. After great struggles, success. This is the way: through the difficulty, not around it. The fellowship that comes easily leaves easily. The fellowship that is fought for, that is chosen again and again through difficulty, this is the fellowship that lasts.

Fellowship in the meadow. No remorse. The meadow is open, wide, without boundaries. Fellowship here is without conditions. No remorse follows because you have not tried to control it, to limit it, to make it something it is not. You have simply shown up in the meadow and let others do the same. This is fellowship as it was meant to be: open, free, without walls. No remorse. Only the quiet joy of being together because you choose to be, not because you have to be.

lower.name: Lí (Fire)
lower.nature: The clinging, the light, the clarity that rises

upper.name: Qián (Heaven)
upper.nature: The creative, the vast, the openness above

trigrams.description: Fire below, heaven above. Fire rises naturally toward heaven; heaven is vast enough to receive it. This is fellowship: the natural attraction of like to like, of light to light. Fire does not try to become heaven; heaven does not try to extinguish fire. Each is itself, and in that being, they are together. This is how people are meant to be: not merged, not separated, but in fellowship.

hexagrams.taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'The sage does not hoard. The more they give to others, the more they have themselves.' Hexagram 13 is the sage's way of being with people. Fellowship in the open field—no hoarding, no guarding, no excluding. The more you give of yourself, the more fellowship you have. The more you try to control it, the less you have. Fire rises to heaven not because it is commanded but because that is its nature. People come together not because they are forced but because they recognize something in each other. This is fellowship: the recognition of shared light. It cannot be manufactured. It can only be allowed. Open the field. Light the fire. Let heaven do the rest.

hexagrams.name: Possession in Great Measure (大有 - Dà Yǒu)
hexagrams.heart: Fire above, heaven below. The sun in the sky, shining on everything. Nothing is hidden. Nothing is withheld. This is possession in great measure—not hoarding but radiating. The fire does not keep its light; it gives it away freely. Heaven does not compete with the sun; it holds it, supports it, allows it to shine. This is true abundance: not what you have but what you are able to give.

ancient.rendering: Possession in Great Measure. Sublime success.

hexagrams.judgment: There is a kind of abundance that does not corrupt, a kind of possession that does not imprison. It is possession in great measure—having much not for yourself but for the world. The sun has much: light, warmth, life. It does not hoard these things. It radiates them. Sublime success comes not from accumulating but from distributing. When you have much, the question is not how to keep it but how to share it. The answer to that question determines whether your abundance is blessing or curse.
hexagrams.image: Fire in heaven above. The image of Possession in Great Measure. Thus the superior person curbs evil and furthers good, and thereby obeys the benevolent will of heaven. Fire in heaven is the sun—the source of all life, the revealer of all things. The wise one, seeing this, does not hoard the light. They curb evil—not through punishment but through clarity. They further good—not through force but through example. In this way, they obey the benevolent will of heaven, which is simply this: that light should shine, that life should flourish, that abundance should be shared.
lines: No relationship with what is harmful. There is no blame in this. If one remains conscious of difficulty, one remains without blame. In great possession, the temptation is to think you are invulnerable. You are not. No relationship with what is harmful—this is the first discipline of abundance. Do not let your wealth, your power, your success connect you to what will diminish you. Remain conscious of difficulty. Remember that you are human. In this remembering, you remain without blame.

A big wagon for loading. One may undertake something. No blame. You have a big wagon—a capacity for much. Load it. Undertake something. Do not let your abundance make you passive. Wealth is not for hoarding; it is for doing. No blame follows action undertaken with the resources you have been given. The wagon is empty for a reason: to be filled, to be used, to move. Load it. Go.

A prince offers it to the Son of Heaven. A petty person cannot do this. When you have much, there is a choice: to keep it or to offer it. The prince offers it to the Son of Heaven—to something larger than themselves. A petty person cannot do this. They can only keep, only hoard, only protect. But you are not petty. You are a prince. Offer what you have. Not because you have to but because you can. This is the joy of great possession: the ability to give.

They make a difference between themselves and their neighbor. No blame. Abundance does not mean you give to everyone equally. You make a difference between yourself and your neighbor—not in worth but in responsibility. You have more; therefore you can give more. This is not arrogance; it is honesty. No blame follows when you recognize your capacity and act from it. Do not pretend you are the same as everyone. You are not. Use that difference for good.

They have truth, which links together. No blame. Truth is the link that holds great possession together. Without truth, abundance becomes corruption. With truth, it becomes blessing. They have truth—not as a concept but as a practice. They link together—not as a transaction but as a commitment. No blame follows because you have not let your wealth separate you from what is real. You have truth. You have each other. You have enough.

They are blessed by heaven. Good fortune. Nothing that does not further. At last, the blessing is complete. Not because you earned it but because you were open to it. Heaven blesses you—not with more things but with more life. Good fortune. Nothing that does not further. This is the ultimate abundance: when everything you do furthers life, when everything you touch is blessed. You did not achieve this. You allowed it. And in the allowing, you became what you were meant to be: a channel for heaven's blessing.

lower.name: Qián (Heaven)
lower.nature: The creative, the strong, the foundation

upper.name: Lí (Fire)
upper.nature: The clinging, the light, the radiance

trigrams.description: Heaven below, fire above. Heaven supports the fire; the fire illuminates heaven. This is possession in great measure: the foundation is strong, the expression is brilliant. Fire in heaven is the sun—the ultimate symbol of abundance. It has everything, yet it gives everything away. This is the paradox of great possession: the more you give, the more you have. Heaven knows this. Fire knows this. You are learning.

hexagrams.taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'To know when you have enough is to be rich. To know when you have too much is to be wise.' Hexagram 14 is the wisdom of enough. Possession in great measure is not about how much you have; it is about how you relate to what you have. The sun has infinite light, yet it does not hoard it. It shines. Heaven has infinite space, yet it does not guard it. It holds. This is the way: to have much and to hold it lightly. To be abundant and to give freely. Sublime success comes not from accumulation but from radiation. Shine. Give. Let heaven hold you. This is enough. This is more than enough.

hexagrams.name: Modesty (謙 - Qiān)
hexagrams.heart: Earth above, mountain below. The mountain does not show its height; it hides beneath the earth. This is modesty—not thinking less of yourself but thinking of yourself less. The mountain is still there, solid, unmoving, but it does not need to be seen. Earth covers it, and in that covering, something deeper is revealed. Modesty is not diminishment. It is the art of being so secure in yourself that you do not need to prove anything.

ancient.rendering: Modesty. Success. The superior person carries things through to the end.

hexagrams.judgment: There is a power in modesty that arrogance can never know. It is the power of the mountain beneath the earth—present, solid, but not demanding attention. Success comes not from announcing yourself but from carrying things through to the end. The superior person does not need to be seen to be effective. They do not need credit to be satisfied.
