They simply do what needs doing, and in that doing, they reveal the deepest kind of strength. Modesty is not weakness. It is strength that does not need to show itself.
hexagrams.image: Within the earth, a mountain. The image of Modesty. Thus the superior person reduces that which is too much, and augments that which is too little. They weigh things and make them equal. The mountain is inside the earth—hidden, but not gone. The wise one, seeing this, does not try to make everything the same. They reduce what is too much and augment what is too little. They weigh things and make them equal—not through force but through attention. This is modesty: knowing what is enough, knowing what is too much, knowing when to step back so others can step forward.
lines: A superior person modest about their modesty. They may cross the great water. Good fortune. There is modesty, and then there is modesty about modesty—not being proud of your humility, not using your modesty as a way to be seen. This is the deepest modesty. The superior person who has this may cross the great water. They may take on the impossible. Good fortune follows because they are not carrying the weight of their own ego. They are light. They can move.

Modesty that comes to expression. Perseverance brings good fortune. Modesty is not meant to be invisible. It comes to expression—in how you speak, how you act, how you treat others. But it is not announced. It is lived. Perseverance in this lived modesty brings good fortune. Not because you are rewarded for being humble but because humility allows you to see clearly, to act wisely, to connect deeply. Good fortune is the natural result of seeing things as they are.

A superior person of modesty and merit carries things to conclusion. Good fortune. Modesty without merit is emptiness. Merit without modesty is arrogance. But modesty and merit together—this is the superior person. They have done the work. They have the results. And they do not need to talk about it. They carry things to conclusion. Good fortune follows because they are not distracted by the need for recognition. They are focused on what matters. And so they finish.

Nothing that would not further modesty in movement. There is no movement that is not enhanced by modesty. Whether you are going forward or stepping back, whether you are leading or following, whether you are speaking or listening—modesty furthers it. This is the universality of modesty. It is not a strategy for certain situations. It is a way of being in all situations. Nothing that would not further. Remember this. Let it guide you.

No boasting of wealth before one's neighbor. It is favorable to attack with force. Nothing that would not further. You have wealth—of resources, of talent, of opportunity. Do not boast of it before your neighbor. This is not just politeness; it is wisdom. Boasting creates distance. Modesty creates connection. And from that connection, you can attack with force—tackle the difficult things, take on the challenges. Nothing that would not further. When you are modest, everything becomes possible.

Modesty that comes to expression. It is favorable to set armies marching to chastise one's own city and one's country. Modesty is not just personal. It is collective. When modesty comes to expression in a community, in a country, it becomes possible to do what is most difficult: to chastise your own city, your own country. To look honestly at what is wrong and to fix it. This is favorable. This is necessary. Modesty allows you to see your own flaws. And in seeing them, to heal them.

lower.name: Gèn (Mountain)
lower.nature: The still, the solid, the unmoving presence

upper.name: Kūn (Earth)
upper.nature: The receptive, the covering, the humble surface

trigrams.description: Mountain below, earth above. The mountain does not show its height. The earth covers it without hiding it. This is modesty: the presence of strength without the need to display it. The mountain is still a mountain. The earth is still earth. But together, they create something deeper than either could alone. Modesty is not the absence of the mountain. It is the mountain choosing to be covered.

hexagrams.taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'The sage wears rough clothing and holds the jewel in their heart.' Hexagram 15 is the sage's way. Modesty is not thinking you are nothing. It is knowing you are something and not needing to prove it. The mountain beneath the earth does not cease to be a mountain. It simply does not announce itself. The sage wears rough clothing—not because they cannot afford better but because they do not need to be seen. The jewel is in the heart, where it belongs. Success comes to the modest not as reward but as recognition. The world sees what you are not trying to show. And in that seeing, you are free. Carry things through. Do not boast. Let the mountain be covered. This is the way.

hexagrams.name: Enthusiasm (豫 - Yù)
hexagrams.heart: Thunder above, earth below. The storm that breaks the drought. Thunder rolls across the sky; earth receives it without resistance. This is enthusiasm—not the shallow excitement of getting what you want but the deep resonance of being aligned with something larger. Thunder does not try to be heard. It simply is. And in its being, everything wakes up. Enthusiasm is not manufactured. It is recognized. It is the sound of your own aliveness.

ancient.rendering: Enthusiasm. It furthers one to install helpers and to set armies marching.

hexagrams.judgment: There is a power in enthusiasm that cannot be faked. It is the power of thunder over earth—the natural authority of something that is genuinely alive. When you are enthusiastic, you do not need to convince others. They feel it. They join. It furthers one to install helpers—not because you cannot do it alone but because enthusiasm is meant to be shared. It furthers one to set armies marching—not toward war but toward purpose. Enthusiasm is not a feeling. It is a force. And like all forces, it can be used well or poorly. Use it well.
hexagrams.image: Thunder comes resounding out of the earth. The image of Enthusiasm. Thus the ancient kings made music in order to honor merit, and offered it with splendor to the Supreme Deity, inviting their ancestors to be present. Thunder from the earth—this is the sound of something awakening. The ancient kings, hearing this, made music. Not for entertainment but for honor. They honored merit, offered it to the Supreme Deity, invited their ancestors to be present. This is what enthusiasm is for: to connect the present with the past, the human with the divine, the small with the large. Music is enthusiasm made audible. Let it be heard.
lines: Enthusiasm that expresses itself brings misfortune. Enthusiasm that is all expression and no substance brings misfortune. Thunder without earth is just noise. If your enthusiasm is only about showing how enthusiastic you are, it will collapse under its own weight. Feel the enthusiasm. Let it move you. But do not make it about you. Make it about what the enthusiasm is for. Otherwise, misfortune.

Firm as a rock. Not a whole day. Perseverance brings good fortune. Enthusiasm needs grounding. Be firm as a rock—not rigid, but solid. And do not wait a whole day to decide. When you know, you know. Perseverance in this knowing brings good fortune. Enthusiasm without grounding is mania. Enthusiasm with grounding is power. Be the rock. Let the thunder roll through you. But do not let it shake you loose from your foundation.

Enthusiasm that looks upward creates remorse. Hesitation brings remorse. There are two mistakes here. One: enthusiasm that looks upward—envying those above, trying to impress those higher, making your enthusiasm about status. This creates remorse. Two: hesitation—holding back when it is time to act, doubting when it is time to move. This also brings remorse. The middle way is enthusiasm that looks forward, not up. Enthusiasm that acts, not hesitates. Find this. Stay here.

The source of enthusiasm. He achieves great things. Doubt not. You gather friends around you as a hair clasp gathers the hair. There is a source of enthusiasm that is not dependent on circumstances. It is within you. When you find it, you achieve great things. Doubt not. And you gather friends—not through effort but through resonance. Like a hair clasp gathers hair, you gather people. They come to you because you are a source. Be this. Trust this. The friends will come.

Persistently ill, and still does not die. When you are persistently ill—stuck in old patterns, old wounds, old ways—and still do not die, there is something to learn. Enthusiasm is not the absence of illness. It is the presence of life despite illness. You have survived. You are still here. This is not a tragedy. It is an opportunity. The enthusiasm that comes from surviving is deeper than the enthusiasm that comes from thriving. Use it. You have earned it.

Deluded enthusiasm. But if after completion one changes, there is no blame. Deluded enthusiasm—enthusiasm for the wrong thing, enthusiasm that is based on illusion, enthusiasm that will lead you astray. This happens. But if, after completion, after you have seen where it led, you change, there is no blame. The blame is not in the delusion. The blame is in staying deluded. Change. Learn. Move on. No blame. Only the wisdom that comes from having been wrong and having admitted it.

lower.name: Kūn (Earth)
lower.nature: The receptive, the yielding, the ground that receives

upper.name: Zhèn (Thunder)
upper.nature: The arousing, the stirring, the sound that wakes

trigrams.description: Earth below, thunder above. Earth receives the thunder without resistance. Thunder rolls across the earth without forcing it. This is enthusiasm: the natural resonance between what moves and what receives. Thunder does not try to wake the earth. The earth does not try to resist the thunder. They simply are. And in that being, everything awakens. This is how enthusiasm works. It is not forced. It is allowed.

hexagrams.taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'The sage does not speak. They teach without words.' Hexagram 16 is the teaching of enthusiasm. Thunder does not speak. It rolls. And in its rolling, everything wakes up. The ancient kings did not lecture. They made music. And in that music, merit was honored, ancestors were present, the divine was near. This is enthusiasm: not the words but the resonance. Not the message but the music. You do not need to convince anyone to be enthusiastic. You need to be enthusiastic. The thunder will do the rest. Let it roll. Let it wake what is sleeping. Let it be heard. This is enough.
